newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES DEPRESSED IN LIQUID MARKET.
newsitem.headline: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES DEPRESSED IN LIQUID MARKET.

text.p: Zimbabwe's money market opened liquid on Thursday with short-term trading rates quoted softer, dealers said.
They said the market closed the previous day with a surplus of Z$202 million, from Tuesday's Z$42.6 million shortage.
The central Reserve Bank on Thursday auctioned 60-day treasury bills worth Z$500 million at 17 percent. This compared with Z$500 million worth of 91-day bills sold at 17.16 percent on Wednesday.
Meanwhile, the central bank paper was being resold on the secondary market at 16.95 percent, down from 17.10 percent.

NCD bills with maturity of 30, 60 and 90 days were quoted at 18.25 and 17 percent (buying and selling respectively) from 18.50 and 17.75 percent while bankers acceptances were being bought at 17.85 percent, down from 18 percent and sold at 16.95 from 17.25 percent. Call money eased to 16.75 percent from 17.50.
